questions.text: What are the key advantages of the Relational Model in DBMS?
options: Data independence, easy data retrieval, and reduced data redundancy.
It supports only hierarchical relationships between data.
It does not allow constraints on data integrity.
It is difficult to normalize and organize data efficiently.
questions.correctAnswer: Data independence, easy data retrieval, and reduced data redundancy.

questions.text: What is a major disadvantage of the Relational Model?
options: High computational cost for complex queries and joins.
Data retrieval is impossible.
It does not support relationships between tables.
It requires a hierarchical structure for efficient processing.
questions.correctAnswer: High computational cost for complex queries and joins.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Codd’s 12 Rules in the Relational Model?
options: To define the characteristics of a truly relational database system.
To establish the rules for indexing in file systems.
To limit the use of SQL queries.
To ensure that only hierarchical databases are used.
questions.correctAnswer: To define the characteristics of a truly relational database system.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of Codd’s 12 Rules?
options: Guaranteed access rule
Systematic treatment of NULL values
Support for hierarchical data model
View updating rule

questions.text: In DBMS, what is a Relation?
options: A table consisting of rows and columns representing structured data.
A single data element stored in a file system.
A function used to retrieve data from a hierarchical database.
An attribute that connects two different databases.
questions.correctAnswer: A table consisting of rows and columns representing structured data.

questions.text: What is the difference between a Schema and a Subschema in a Relational Model?
options: A schema defines the overall database structure, while a subschema defines a specific view of the database for users.
Schemas are used only for indexing, while subschemas store relationships.
Subschemas define the entire database, while schemas are just small parts of it.
There is no difference between a schema and a subschema.
questions.correctAnswer: A schema defines the overall database structure, while a subschema defines a specific view of the database for users.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a Relational Model Constraint?
options: Domain Constraint
Tuple Uniqueness Constraint
File System Constraint
Integrity Constraint

questions.text: What does the Key Constraint ensure in a Relational Model?
options: Every tuple (row) in a relation is uniquely identifiable using a key attribute.
Only one relation can exist in a database.
All tables must be normalized to the highest level.
It restricts the number of tables in a database.
questions.correctAnswer: Every tuple (row) in a relation is uniquely identifiable using a key attribute.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an Integrity Constraint in DBMS?
options: Foreign key constraints ensure referential integrity between tables.
Tables must be stored in hierarchical order.
Only primary keys are allowed in a relation.
Data can be stored without any validation checks.
questions.correctAnswer: Foreign key constraints ensure referential integrity between tables.

questions.text: Which of the following is a basic Relational Algebra operation?
options: Union
Grouping
Sorting
Indexing

questions.text: What is the Cartesian Product operation in Relational Algebra?
options: It combines every row of one relation with every row of another relation.
It selects a subset of attributes from a relation.
It removes duplicate rows from a relation.
It filters tuples based on a given condition.
questions.correctAnswer: It combines every row of one relation with every row of another relation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an Additional Relational Algebra Operation?
options: Projection
Sorting
Clustering
Normalization

questions.text: How does the Join operation work in Relational Algebra?
options: It combines two relations based on a common attribute.
It removes duplicate values from a table.
It adds new columns to an existing table.
It converts tables into a hierarchical structure.
questions.correctAnswer: It combines two relations based on a common attribute.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Rename operation in Relational Algebra?
options: To rename the attributes or relation name without changing data.
To delete duplicate records from a relation.
To merge two different tables.
To create a copy of an existing relation.
questions.correctAnswer: To rename the attributes or relation name without changing data.

questions.text: Why is it necessary to convert an E-R Model to a Relational Model?
options: To store data in a structured tabular format suitable for relational databases.
To remove relationships between entities.
To ensure that data follows a hierarchical structure.
To eliminate the need for database normalization.
questions.correctAnswer: To store data in a structured tabular format suitable for relational databases.
